title: Who is your favorite classical composer and why? - Quora

response.answer_text: For me, it’s no competition: J. S. Bach. Here are a few reasons why: In my opinion, music is equal parts technique and expression; in other words, the best music isn’t just that which is technically perfect or expressively rich, but both. Obviously, your personal mileage may vary, but for my money, no composer did both as well as, or melded the two together better than, J. S. Bach. For example, let’s turn to the “Crucifixus” and “Et Resurrexit” sections of the B Minor Mass. These two sections, one right after the other, are intended to portray the absolute extremes of human emotion — despair and suffering on one hand; joy and exuberance on the other — and wow, do they ever! This is remarkable on its own, but the fact that the music is also so technically perfect, that it holds up so well to analysis, makes it even more so.Bach was a devout Lutheran, and much of his music (even his instrumental music) can be linked back to his Christian faith. Now, I’m not suggesting that you need to be a person of faith to appreciate Bach — the late Douglas Adams was an extreme atheist (his term), and he adored Bach’s music — but I am saying that, as a Christian, I feel a particular kinship to Bach and his work.Two personal recollections: Before I ever started composing, I was a percussionist, and when I was in high school, my (rather unorthodox) percussion teacher suggested that I pick up a copy of Glenn Gould’s 1955 recording of Bach’s Goldberg Variations. I was instantly hooked, and I listened to that recording for months on end. Also, I will never forget the first time I listened to the opening “Kyrie” from the B Minor Mass. I was following along with the score, and I couldn’t help but weep, because I knew I was listening to the most beautiful music I had ever heard. If not for these two run-ins with the music of Bach, I don’t know that I would be a composer. For that reason, if no other, I am indebted to Bach.I could go on, but you get the idea. My point is that Bach is my favorite composer not only because of the ridiculously high quality of his music, or because of its expressive power, or because of my personal connections to it, but for all of those reasons combined.

My favorite composer, and I’m sure many would agree with me, is Ludwig Van Beethoven. Beethoven was a German-Classical composer who lived between the years 1770–1827. What makes Beethoven’s many compositions so breathtakingly spectacular is not only the many dynamic contrasts and musical complexity they exhibit, but the heavy emotional weight they carry. Unknown to many, a great deal of Beethoven’s arrangements reflect the complex feelings he was experiencing at the time of their composition. An excellent example of Beethoven’s emotional investment in his music is evident in his composition of the well-known “Moonlight Sonata.” This sonata was not composed thoughtlessly, but with Beethoven’s pupil Giulietta Guicciardi in mind. Beethoven’s infatuation and love for Guicciardi is evident in the emotional intensity of the piece. Another prime example of Beethoven’s emotional investment in his music is evident in his “Pastoral Symphony.” This composition contains five movements, each with a different feeling. The first movement reflects Beethoven’s feelings as he first arrives in the country, the second movement encapsulates the sound of flowing water, the third movement paints the image of country folk dancing, the fourth movement depicts a violent thunderstorm, and the fifth (and final) movement represents the humble sheperds’ song of thanksgiving. Beethoven’s musical genius is clear from these few examples. His emotional intensity and attention to music make him my favorite composer.
